When something fails during the early phase of the execution (for instance: the
launched process dies immediately because of a bad classpath, or does not
instantiate a control agent), the TestExecutionHarnessExecutorStub waits for
about one minute and then gives up (the following exception is logged:
org.eclipse.hyades.internal.execution.local.control.InactiveProcessException
	at
org.eclipse.hyades.execution.harness.TestExecutionHarnessExecutorStub.launch(TestExecutionHarnessExecutorStub.java:192)
	at
org.eclipse.hyades.execution.harness.TestExecutionHarness.launchTestExecution(TestExecutionHarness.java:1512)
	at
org.eclipse.hyades.execution.harness.TestExecutionHarness.access$0(TestExecutionHarness.java:1299)
	at
org.eclipse.hyades.execution.harness.TestExecutionHarness$1.run(TestExecutionHarness.java:1215)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:66))
But the job that is monitoring the execution progress never terminates, and it
cannot be cancelled. I suggest one of the following, in order of preference:
1) The executor should go a "dead" state in such a situation, so that the
execution progress job doesn't wait forever.
2) The execution job should be cancellable, so the user may get rid of this
progress information. The problem here is what to do when the user clicks on
cancel while the execution is actually being performed? Kill the process, or
just remove the progress indication?

Per suggestion of reporter, the error code now sets the execution component to 
the DEAD state so the execution progress job picks up the end of the run 
correctly.
